segment.source: 4944(S) The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.
segment.target: 4944(S) The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4944(S) The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.
segment.target: Describes security event 4944(S) The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.

segment.source: 4944(S): The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.
segment.target: 4944(S): The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time Windows Firewall service starts.
segment.target: This event generates every time Windows Firewall service starts.

segment.source: This event shows Windows Firewall settings that were in effect when the Windows Firewall service started.
segment.target: This event shows Windows Firewall settings that were in effect when the Windows Firewall service started.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Group Policy Applied Type = UnicodeString: it always has “No” value for this event.
segment.target: Group Policy Applied Type = UnicodeString: it always has “No” value for this event.

segment.source: This field should show information about: was Group Policy applied for Windows Firewall when it starts or not.
segment.target: This field should show information about: was Group Policy applied for Windows Firewall when it starts or not.

segment.source: Profile Used Type = UnicodeString: shows the active profile name for the moment Windows Firewall service starts.
segment.target: Profile Used Type = UnicodeString: shows the active profile name for the moment Windows Firewall service starts.

segment.source: It always has value “Public” for this event, because when this event generates, the active profile is not switched to “Domain” or “Private”.
segment.target: It always has value “Public” for this event, because when this event generates, the active profile is not switched to “Domain” or “Private”.

segment.source: Typically you will see “4956(S): Windows Firewall has changed the active profile” after this event, which will tell you the real active profile.
segment.target: Typically you will see “4956(S): Windows Firewall has changed the active profile” after this event, which will tell you the real active profile.

segment.source: Operational mode Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Operational mode Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: On – if “Firewall state:” setting was set to “On” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: On – if “Firewall state:” setting was set to “On” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Off - if “Firewall state:” setting was set to “Off” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Off - if “Firewall state:” setting was set to “Off” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Allow Remote Administration Type = UnicodeString: looks like this setting is connected to ”Windows Firewall: Allow remote administration exception” Group Policy setting, but it is always Disabled, no matter which option is set for “Windows Firewall: Allow remote administration exception” Group Policy.
segment.target: Allow Remote Administration Type = UnicodeString: looks like this setting is connected to ”Windows Firewall: Allow remote administration exception” Group Policy setting, but it is always Disabled, no matter which option is set for “Windows Firewall: Allow remote administration exception” Group Policy.

segment.source: Allow Unicast Responses to Multicast/Broadcast Traffic Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Allow Unicast Responses to Multicast/Broadcast Traffic Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: Enabled - if “Allow unicast response:” Settings configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Enabled - if “Allow unicast response:” Settings configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Disabled - if “Allow unicast response:” Settings configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Disabled - if “Allow unicast response:” Settings configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Security Logging:
segment.target: Security Logging:

segment.source: Log Dropped Packets Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Log Dropped Packets Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: Enabled – if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Enabled – if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Disabled - if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Disabled - if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Log Successful Connections Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Log Successful Connections Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: Enabled - if “Log successful connections:” Logging configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Enabled - if “Log successful connections:” Logging configuration was set to “Yes” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Disabled - if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.
segment.target: Disabled - if “Log dropped packets:” Logging configuration was set to “No” for “Public” profile.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4944(S): The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.
segment.target: For 4944(S): The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started.

segment.source: If you have a standard or baseline for Windows Firewall settings defined for Public profile (which can be the same as for Domain, for example), monitor this event and check whether the settings reported by the event are still the same as were defined in your standard or baseline.
segment.target: If you have a standard or baseline for Windows Firewall settings defined for Public profile (which can be the same as for Domain, for example), monitor this event and check whether the settings reported by the event are still the same as were defined in your standard or baseline.

segment.source: Unfortunately this event shows configuration only for Public profile, but you can still compare all the settings with your organization's Windows Firewall baseline for Public profile on different computers and trigger an alert if the configuration is not the same.
segment.target: Unfortunately this event shows configuration only for Public profile, but you can still compare all the settings with your organization's Windows Firewall baseline for Public profile on different computers and trigger an alert if the configuration is not the same.
